Situation1: They encounter a customer trying to return an item without a receipt and need to apply the store’s return policy.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: Late-evening music plans overlap with the building’s quiet hours while a neighbor’s windows are open.
Story:
I stood behind the register, scanning items as the line inched forward. A woman approached, holding a blender and looking flustered. “I lost my receipt, but it’s broken. Can I return it?” she pleaded. Store policy was clear: no returns without proof of purchase. My manager expected me to enforce the rules, but the woman’s anxious eyes made me hesitate. I wanted to help, but I also had to follow procedures.

Later that evening, I was excited to play music with friends in my apartment. We’d planned this for weeks, but as I set up my speakers, I remembered the building’s quiet hours had just started. My neighbor’s windows were open, and I could hear her TV. As a citizen, I knew I should respect her right to peace and follow the building’s rules. But my friends were already buzzing with anticipation.

The weight of these expectations pressed on me—at work, I was supposed to be firm and impersonal; at home, considerate and law-abiding. I felt torn, caught between doing what was right for the store, for my neighbor, and for myself.
